title: Virgin Australia edges closer to $700m Velocity takeover
text:
Virgin Australia's takeover of frequent flyer business Velocity has received a $US425 million ($623.25 million) boost from American investors.

Virgin Australia also told investors it had received FIRB approval. James Alcock

Still, the airline will now look locally to obtain the remaining funds required for the acquisition of Affinity Equity Partner's 35 per cent stake in the business, which will cost Virgin Australia a total of $700 million.

It is now planning a roadshow similar to the one used to fundraise in the US where Australian investors will get the chance to purchase short-term notes – a debt that Virgin Australia will pay back when it reaches maturity.

The new funds represent the latest chapter in the airline's crusade to fully acquire Velocity in which it already holds a 65 per cent stake.

Affinity first confirmed it would walk away from the frequent flyer business after five years in July after Street Talk revealed its intentions. What followed was Virgin Australia's confirmation that it had entered a deal with the private equity operator to purchase its stake.

Virgin Australia also told investors that it had received Foreign Investment Review Board approval for the takeover of Velocity – a certification required due to the airlines complex ownership structure that includes foreign airlines, including the overarching Virgin Group.
